column1: Cinco Ranch is a census-designated place and master-planned community located in the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city of Houston within Fort Bend and Harris counties in the U.S. state of Texas. The population was 18
column2: 274 at the 2010 census. It lies about 25 miles (40 km) west of the Harris County seat of Houston and 10 miles (16 km) north of the Fort Bend County seat of Richmond. Cinco Ranch is considered to be part of the Greater Katy area and is roughly 10 miles southeast of the city of Katy.

column1: The Cinco Ranch community goes back to before Texas became a republic. In the 1820s
column2: pioneer Moses Austin was granted by the Spanish government the authority to settle 300 families in the valleys of the Brazos and Colorado rivers. He died before he was able to accomplish this
column3: but his son Stephen F. Austin was able to complete his father's wishes

column1: Cinco Ranch has a growing network of greenbelt trails
column3: bike or rollerblade between almost anywhere in Cinco Ranch
column4: including recreational facilities and schools in the community. The multi-station Exer-Trail is for workouts. There is also the Bayou Nature Trail
column5: extending nearly four miles and preserving almost 70 acres (280
column6: 000 m2) of woodland and wetland habitat.  Plans are currently underway to connect the Bayou Nature Trail to the Buffalo Bayou Hike And Bike Trail.  This will allow residents of Cinco Ranch to ride their bikes from the Grand Parkway to Beltway 8 - a 26-mile (42 km) bike trail.

column1: The YMCA offers free Child Watch and Kid Watch services for members. The YMCA also offers Before and After School programs for children ages 5–12 in most KISD elementary schools. Other activities include Spring Break and Winter Break camps.
The YMCA's youth sports programs include soccer
column4: basketball and baseball. Other youth activities include Taekwondo

column1: The YMCA was originally named after Ken Lay; in the wake of the corruption scandal that led to the downfall of Enron Corporation
column2: a major Houston-based energy company which Lay headed
column3: he asked for his name to be removed from the YMCA in June 2006

column1: The Katy Amateur Radio Society (KARS) has about 45 amateur radio operators.[1] The KARS net operates every Tuesday at 8:00 PM on the KT5TX 147.20 MHz repeater. KARS monthly meetings are held on the 2nd Monday of every month at the West I-10 Fire Station #4 on Franz just east of Grand Parkway.[2]

As of 2019 The Village School in the Energy Corridor area has a bus service to Cinco Ranch.
The Houston Community College System serves Cinco Ranch. The Northwest College's Katy Campus is in an unincorporated section of Harris County.
Cinco Ranch is served by the Cinco Ranch Branch Library of the Fort Bend County Libraries system
column2: located across from Cinco Ranch High School and one block from Texas State Highway 99 (Grand Parkway). The library first opened as the Katy/Fort Bend Branch Library in a room on the campus of the University of Houston System at Cinco Ranch in June 1998. In 1999 the branch
column4: moved to the former Cinco Ranch development company sales office as a result of the efforts of the Katy/Fort Bend Friends. The community asked for a larger library
column5: and Fort Bend County judge Jim Adolphus organized efforts to have a library established. Adolphus negotiated the donation of a library site from Terrabrook
column7: and secured a challenge grant. In addition
column8: Adolphus and Fort Bend County judge candidate Bob Hebert co-hosted a fundraising gala for the challenge grant. The Cinco Ranch community
column9: led by the Katy/Fort Bend Friends association
